Certainly, here is a list of actionable solutions and recommendations that can be considered by policy-makers to address the fine dust pollution problem in South Korea:

Domestic Solutions
------------------

* Implement stronger regulations and enforcement on emissions from domestic sources, such as power plants, transportation, and industrial activities.
	+ This can include measures such as transitioning to cleaner energy sources, implementing emissions standards, and promoting the use of clean technologies.
	+ The government can also provide incentives for individuals and businesses to adopt more sustainable practices, such as using energy-efficient vehicles and appliances.
* Develop and implement a comprehensive monitoring and reporting system for air quality.
	+ This system should regularly monitor fine dust levels, as well as other pollutants, and make this information publicly available.
	+ The government can also use this information to identify areas and activities that contribute to air pollution and target enforcement efforts accordingly.
* Promote public awareness and education about the health and environmental impacts of fine dust pollution.
	+ This can include public campaigns, educational materials for schools, and outreach programs for communities.
	+ By raising awareness and understanding, individuals can take steps to reduce their own contributions to air pollution.

Regional and International Solutions
------------------------------------

* Increase cooperation and collaboration with neighboring countries, such as China, to address transboundary air pollution.
	+ This can include sharing data and information, developing joint initiatives and action plans, and working together to reduce emissions from major sources.
	+ The government can also encourage international organizations, such as the United Nations, to play a role in promoting cooperation and coordination among countries.
* Promote the use of clean technologies and the transition to cleaner energy sources at the regional and international level.
	+ This can include initiatives to increase the deployment of renewable energy, such as wind and solar, and support the development of clean technologies, such as electric vehicles.
	+ The government can also participate in international negotiations and agreements, such as the Paris Agreement, to drive global action on climate change and air pollution.
* Implement regional and international agreements and regulations on air pollution and emissions.
	+ This can include agreements and regulations on fine dust pollution, as well as other pollutants, to ensure that countries take action to reduce emissions and protect public health.
	+ The government can also advocate for stronger international action and accountability for countries that are major sources of air pollution.

In conclusion, addressing the fine dust pollution problem in South Korea requires a multi-faceted approach that involves both domestic and international solutions. By taking action on a range of fronts, policy-makers can work towards a cleaner, healthier future for all.
